title: Is there any true randomness in the universe? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well… this depends on what you mean by “truly random”. If you mean “not determined only by factors from the past”, then we already are pretty certain that every single subatomic transaction is “truly random”, and the apparent causality we see is due to the extremely low probabilities of anything happening that *appears* non-causal. Bell’s Theorem basically proves that no *local* hidden variables can result in the results we see from quantum mechanics… so it’s not just that we haven’t found them yet… they can’t exist. However, a “non-local” hidden variable would be an effect from the future, not from the past… so by the definition I gave above wouldn’t be satisfied. If you’re ok with causality coming from the future, then pure “determinism” by that definition might be possible. We don’t know.

Probably not. (at least in the sense of not having a pattern) Quantum vacuum fluctuations / virtual particles / quantum foam seem to come closest. And I suspect they are the result of forces acting upon them. The thing is that those forces may be outside our universe. So we may not find out. We also cannot currently explain atomic decay - we can know the half-life of an isotope but we can not predict when any particular atom will decay. This may turn out to be explained by virtual particles. We may one day work all this out, but I doubt that it is happening without a process that could be explained and understood given sufficient information. Those fluctuations explain a lot of things that we currently can’t exactly predict, they create noise in our systems and therefore slight differences in outcomes. Also we consider throwing dice to be random but that really is just our way of saying we don’t have the degree of depth of data handling and perception to predict the outcome. Too many variables for us to deal with. Which doesn’t mean that given the sensing technology and sufficient processing power we couldn’t predict the outcome, making it non-random. There is a statistics definition of random though in which I am wrong - and that the tossing of a coin is random. I assume you meant the idea that events are not based on explainable and possibly predictable processes though?
